title: Authors and Citation
text: José Evandeilton Lopes. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lopes J (2025). gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models Bounded Data. R package version 0.1.1, https://github.com/evandeilton/gkwreg2.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models for Bounded Data},   author = {José Evandeilton Lopes},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.1},   url = {https://github.com/evandeilton/gkwreg2}, }

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: gkwreg2 package provides comprehensive computationally efficient framework regression modeling data restricted standard unit interval (0,1)(0, 1), including proportions, rates, fractions, percentages, bounded indices. alternative implementation gkwreg package, using pure RcppArmadillo analytical gradients instead TMB. result lighter package fewer dependencies maintaining full API compatibility.

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: Model bounded data using 5-parameter Generalized Kumaraswamy (GKw) distribution seven nested subfamilies:

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: Extended formula syntax parameter-specific linear predictors: Example: yield ~ batch + temp | temp | 1 | temp | batch Multiple link functions: Positive parameters (α, β, γ, λ): log (default), sqrt, inverse, identity Probability parameters (δ ∈ (0,1)): logit (default), probit, cloglog, cauchy Flexible optimization via gkw_control(): Multiple optimizers: nlminb (default), BFGS, L-BFGS-B, Nelder-Mead, CG Custom starting values, convergence tolerances, iteration limits
code: y ~ alpha_predictors | beta_predictors | gamma_predictors | delta_predictors | lambda_predictors

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: RcppArmadillo-powered estimation: Compiled C++ analytical gradients gkwdist. Robust optimization: Parameter clamping prevents invalid values optimization. Moment-based starting values: Intelligent initialization faster convergence.

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: Standard R Methods (familiar workflow): summary(), print(), coef(), vcov(), confint() logLik(), AIC(), BIC(), nobs() fitted(), residuals(), predict() anova() nested model comparisons plot() diagnostic plots

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
code: # Install companion distribution package (required): # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("evandeilton/gkwdist")  # Install gkwreg2: remotes::install_github("evandeilton/gkwreg2")

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
code: library(gkwreg2) library(gkwdist)  # Simulate data set.seed(123) n <- 500 x1 <- runif(n, -2, 2) x2 <- rnorm(n)  # True parameters (log link) alpha_true <- exp(0.8 + 0.3 * x1) beta_true <- exp(1.2 - 0.2 * x2)  # Generate response from Kumaraswamy distribution y <- rkw(n, alpha = alpha_true, beta = beta_true) y <- pmax(pmin(y, 1 - 1e-7), 1e-7)  # Ensure strict bounds df <- data.frame(y = y, x1 = x1, x2 = x2)  # Fit Kumaraswamy regression # Formula: alpha ~ x1, beta ~ x2 fit_kw <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1 | x2, data = df, family = "kw")  # View results summary(fit_kw)

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
code: # Fit nested models fit0 <- gkwreg2(y ~ 1, data = df, family = "kw")       # Null model fit1 <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1, data = df, family = "kw")      # + x1 fit2 <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1 | x2, data = df, family = "kw") # + x2 on beta  # Information criteria comparison AIC(fit0, fit1, fit2)  # Likelihood ratio tests anova(fit0, fit1, fit2, test = "Chisq")

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
code: # Create prediction grid newdata <- data.frame(   x1 = seq(-2, 2, length.out = 100),   x2 = 0 )  # Predict different quantities pred_mean <- predict(fit_kw, newdata, type = "response")    # E(Y|X) pred_params <- predict(fit_kw, newdata, type = "parameters") # All parameters pred_quant <- predict(fit_kw, newdata, type = "quantile",                        at = c(0.1, 0.5, 0.9))                 # Quantiles

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
code: # All diagnostic plots par(mfrow = c(3, 2)) plot(fit_kw, ask = FALSE)  # Select specific plots plot(fit_kw, which = c(2, 6))  # Q-Q and Obs vs Pred only

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
code: # Default control fit <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1, data = df, family = "kw")  # Increase iterations for difficult problems fit_robust <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1, data = df, family = "kw",   control = gkw_control(maxit = 1000, trace = 1) )  # Use BFGS optimizer fit_bfgs <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1, data = df, family = "kw",   control = gkw_control(method = "BFGS") )  # Fast fitting without standard errors fit_fast <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1, data = df, family = "kw",   control = gkw_control(hessian = FALSE) )  # Custom starting values fit_custom <- gkwreg2(y ~ x1 + x2 | x3, data = df, family = "kw",   control = gkw_control(     start = list(       alpha = c(0.5, 0.2, -0.1),  # Intercept + 2 slopes       beta  = c(1.0, 0.3)         # Intercept + 1 slope     )   ) )

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: use gkwreg2: Need flexible bounded distributions beyond Beta. Want lighter dependencies TMB. Prefer analytical gradients automatic differentiation. Full compatibility gkwreg workflow.

title: gkwreg2 - Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression
text: Reference Manual: help(package = "gkwreg2") Function Help: ?gkwreg2, ?predict.gkwreg2, ?plot.gkwreg2, ?gkw_control GitHub Issues: Report bugs request features

title: ANOVA for gkwreg2 Objects — anova.gkwreg2
text: object fitted gkwreg2 object. ... Additional gkwreg2 objects compare. test Type test: "Chisq" "LRT" (equivalent), "none" suppress p-values.

title: ANOVA for gkwreg2 Objects — anova.gkwreg2
text: data frame class "anova" columns: Model Model identifier Df Degrees freedom (number parameters) LogLik Log-likelihood AIC Akaike Information Criterion BIC Bayesian Information Criterion Chisq Likelihood ratio test statistic (vs previous model) Df diff Difference degrees freedom Pr(>Chisq) P-value chi-squared distribution

title: ANOVA for gkwreg2 Objects — anova.gkwreg2
text: Models nested valid likelihood ratio tests. function compares model previous one list, computing: $$LRT = -2(\ell_0 - \ell_1)$$ \(\ell_0\) log-likelihood simpler model.

title: ANOVA for gkwreg2 Objects — anova.gkwreg2
code: # \donttest{ # Generate test data set.seed(123) n <- 150 x <- rnorm(n) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = exp(0.5 + 0.2 * x), beta = exp(1)) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x)  # Compare nested models fit0 <- gkwreg2(y ~ 1, data = df, family = "kw") fit1 <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") fit2 <- gkwreg2(y ~ x | x, data = df, family = "kw")  anova(fit0, fit1, fit2) #> Analysis of Variance Table (Likelihood Ratio Tests) #>  #> Family: kw #> n = 150 #>  #>                    Model Df LogLik    AIC    BIC    Chisq Df diff Pr(>Chisq) #> Model 1: y ~ 1         1  2  19.11 -34.21 -28.19       NA      NA         NA #> Model 2: y ~ x         2  3  30.75 -55.51 -46.47 -23.2931       1          1 #> Model 3: y ~ x | x     3  4  31.04 -54.09 -42.04  -0.5802       1          1 #>                    Signif #> Model 1: y ~ 1            #> Model 2: y ~ x            #> Model 3: y ~ x | x        #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 # }

title: Extract Coefficients from gkwreg2 Object — coef.gkwreg2
text: object fitted gkwreg2 object. parameter Optional: name specific parameter extract. flatten Logical: TRUE, return single named vector. ... Currently ignored.

title: Extract Coefficients from gkwreg2 Object — coef.gkwreg2
text: flatten = FALSE (default), named list coefficient vectors per parameter. flatten = TRUE, single named vector.

title: Extract Coefficients from gkwreg2 Object — coef.gkwreg2
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(123) n <- 100 x <- rnorm(n) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = exp(0.5 + 0.2 * x), beta = exp(1)) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x) fit <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") coef(fit) # Vector format (default) #> alpha:(Intercept)           alpha:x  beta:(Intercept)  #>         0.4928363         0.2596803         1.0420609  coef(fit, flatten = FALSE) # List format #> $alpha #> (Intercept)           x  #>   0.4928363   0.2596803  #>  #> $beta #> (Intercept)  #>    1.042061  #>  coef(fit, parameter = "alpha") #> (Intercept)           x  #>   0.4928363   0.2596803  # }

title: Compare Multiple gkwreg2 Models — compare_models
text: convenience function model comparison using AIC, BIC, log-likelihood.

title: Compare Multiple gkwreg2 Models — compare_models
code: compare_models(..., criterion = c("AIC", "BIC", "logLik"))

title: Compare Multiple gkwreg2 Models — compare_models
text: ... gkwreg2 objects compare. criterion Comparison criterion: "AIC" (default), "BIC", "logLik".

title: Compare Multiple gkwreg2 Models — compare_models
text: data frame model comparison statistics.

title: Compare Multiple gkwreg2 Models — compare_models
code: # \donttest{ # Generate test data set.seed(123) n <- 150 x <- rnorm(n) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = exp(0.5 + 0.2 * x), beta = exp(1)) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x)  fit_kw <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") fit_beta <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "beta") compare_models(fit_kw, fit_beta) #>      Model Family Df   LogLik       AIC       BIC Delta_AIC #> 1 fit_beta   beta  3 31.09726 -56.19451 -47.16261 0.0000000 #> 2   fit_kw     kw  3 30.75295 -55.50590 -46.47400 0.6886098 # }

title: Get Default Link Functions for Family — get_default_links
text: Parameter spaces family: kw: alpha > 0, beta > 0 beta: gamma > 0, delta > 0 (shape1, shape2) ekw: alpha > 0, beta > 0, lambda > 0 mc: gamma > 0, delta > 0, lambda > 0 bkw: alpha > 0, beta > 0, gamma > 0, delta > 0 kkw: alpha > 0, beta > 0, delta > 0, lambda > 0 gkw: alpha > 0, beta > 0, gamma > 0, delta > 0, lambda > 0 parameters strictly positive, log link natural choice maps R -> (0, inf).

what: Get Starting Values for Optimization — get_starting_values
title: Get Starting Values for Optimization — get_starting_values
text: Computes robust starting values regression coefficients using moment matching based sample mean variance. crucial optimizers like BFGS handle bounds.

title: Get Starting Values for Optimization — get_starting_values
code: get_starting_values(y, X_list, family, link, control = NULL)

title: Get Starting Values for Optimization — get_starting_values
text: y Response vector (values (0,1)). X_list Named list design matrices. family Distribution family. link Named list link functions. control Control parameters (optional).

title: Get Starting Values for Optimization — get_starting_values
text: Named numeric vector starting values.

title: Get Starting Values for Optimization — get_starting_values
text: function uses moment matching possible: Kumaraswamy: approximate based sample mean Beta: use method moments (gamma, delta mean variance) others: use reasonable default values ensure stability starting values chosen well within valid parameter space avoid boundary issues optimization.

what: Control Parameters for gkwreg2 Fitting — gkw_control
title: Control Parameters for gkwreg2 Fitting — gkw_control
text: Specifies control parameters optimization algorithm used gkwreg2.

title: Control Parameters for gkwreg2 Fitting — gkw_control
code: gkw_control(   method = c("nlminb", "BFGS", "Nelder-Mead", "CG", "L-BFGS-B"),   maxit = 1000L,   reltol = 1e-08,   trace = 0L,   hessian = TRUE,   start = NULL,   keep_data = TRUE,   use_gradient = TRUE )

title: Control Parameters for gkwreg2 Fitting — gkw_control
text: method Optimization method. One "nlminb" (default), "BFGS", "Nelder-Mead", "CG", "L-BFGS-B". maxit Maximum number iterations (default 1000). reltol Relative convergence tolerance (default 1e-8). trace Integer trace level: 0 = silent (default), 1+ = verbose. hessian Logical; TRUE (default), compute Hessian standard error estimation. start Optional named list starting values coefficients. keep_data Logical; TRUE (default), keep data fitted object. use_gradient Logical; TRUE (default), use analytical gradient.

title: Control Parameters for gkwreg2 Fitting — gkw_control
text: list control parameters class "gkw_control".

title: Control Parameters for gkwreg2 Fitting — gkw_control
code: # Default control ctrl <- gkw_control()  # Use BFGS with more iterations ctrl <- gkw_control(method = "BFGS", maxit = 2000)  # Disable Hessian computation for speed ctrl <- gkw_control(hessian = FALSE)

what: gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models — gkwreg2-package
title: gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models — gkwreg2-package
text: gkwreg2 package provides regression modeling bounded data (0,1) using Generalized Kumaraswamy distribution family. implements maximum likelihood estimation analytical gradients via RcppArmadillo.

title: gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models — gkwreg2-package
text: gkw: Generalized Kumaraswamy (5 parameters: α, β, γ, δ, λ) bkw: Beta-Kumaraswamy (4 parameters: α, β, γ, δ) kkw: Kumaraswamy-Kumaraswamy (4 parameters: α, β, δ, λ) ekw: Exponentiated Kumaraswamy (3 parameters: α, β, λ) mc: McDonald (3 parameters: γ, δ, λ) kw: Kumaraswamy (2 parameters: α, β) beta: Beta (2 parameters: γ, δ)

title: gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models — gkwreg2-package
text: gkwreg2: Main model fitting function gkw_control: Control parameters optimization get_param_names: Get parameter names family get_default_links: Get default link functions

title: gkwreg2: Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Models — gkwreg2-package
text: Evandeilton Lopes

what: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
text: Fits regression models bounded (0,1) data using Generalized Kumaraswamy distribution family. Supports extended formula syntax specifying different covariates distribution parameter.

title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
code: gkwreg2(   formula,   data,   family = c("gkw", "bkw", "kkw", "ekw", "mc", "kw", "beta"),   link = NULL,   start = NULL,   control = gkw_control(),   ... )

title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
text: formula extended formula syntax y ~ x1 | x2 | ... part separated | corresponds distribution parameter. Use Formula package syntax. data data frame containing variables formula. family Distribution family. One "gkw", "bkw", "kkw", "ekw", "mc", "kw", "beta". link Optional named list link functions parameter. Default: "log" positive parameters, "logit" probability parameters. See Details. start Optional named list starting values coefficients. control list control parameters gkw_control. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
text: object class "gkwreg2" components: coefficients Named list coefficient vectors per parameter vcov Variance-covariance matrix (Hessian computed) se Standard errors (Hessian computed) loglik Maximized log-likelihood fitted.values Fitted response means residuals Response residuals (y - fitted) converged Logical: optimization converge? family Distribution family used link Link functions used formula Original formula data Original data (keep_data = TRUE) call Matched call n Number observations npar Total number parameters

title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
text: extended formula uses | separate specifications different parameters. order matches parameter order family: kw: y ~ alpha_formula | beta_formula beta: y ~ gamma_formula | delta_formula ekw: y ~ alpha | beta | lambda etc. Unspecified parts default intercept-models.

title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
text: Available links: positive parameters: "log" (default), "sqrt", "inverse", "identity" probability parameters: "logit" (default), "probit", "cloglog", "cauchy"

title: Fit Generalized Kumaraswamy Regression Model — gkwreg2
code: # \donttest{ # Simulate Kumaraswamy data set.seed(123) n <- 200 x <- rnorm(n) alpha <- exp(0.5 + 0.3 * x) beta <- exp(1.0) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = alpha, beta = beta) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x)  # Fit Kumaraswamy regression fit <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") summary(fit) #>  #> Call: #> gkwreg2(formula = y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") #>  #> Family: kw  #> Link functions: alpha = log, beta = log  #>  #> Residuals: #>       Min        1Q    Median        3Q       Max  #> -0.386021 -0.151330 -0.008634  0.154157  0.520779  #>  #> Coefficients: #>  #> --- ALPHA --- #>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept)  0.49668    0.07444   6.672 2.52e-11 *** #> x            0.32640    0.04902   6.658 2.77e-11 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> --- BETA --- #>             Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept)   0.9832     0.1125    8.74   <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> --- #> Log-Likelihood: 45.53 on 197 Df #> AIC: -85.06   BIC: -75.17 #> Number of observations: 200 #> Number of parameters: 3 #> Converged in 15 iterations #>   # Different covariates per parameter fit2 <- gkwreg2(y ~ x | 1, data = df, family = "kw")  # Beta regression fit_beta <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "beta") # }

what: Compute gradient of negative log-likelihood for gkwreg2 — gradient_gkwreg
title: Compute gradient of negative log-likelihood for gkwreg2 — gradient_gkwreg
text: Uses chain rule: ∂ℓ/∂β_p = Xᵀ_p × (∂ℓ/∂θ_p × ∂θ_p/∂η_p)

title: Diagnostic Plots for gkwreg2 Objects — plot.gkwreg2
text: Produces diagnostic plots assessing model fit detecting influential observations.

title: Diagnostic Plots for gkwreg2 Objects — plot.gkwreg2
code: # S3 method for class 'gkwreg2' plot(   x,   which = 1:6,   type = c("quantile", "pearson", "deviance", "response"),   ask = interactive() && length(which) > 1,   id.n = 3,   labels = NULL,   ... )

title: Diagnostic Plots for gkwreg2 Objects — plot.gkwreg2
text: x fitted gkwreg2 object. Integer vector specifying plots produce: 1 Residuals vs Index 2 Q-Q Plot residuals 3 Residuals vs Fitted Values 4 Cook's Distance (available) 5 Histogram residuals 6 Observed vs Predicted type Residual type plots 1-3, 5: "quantile" (default), "pearson", "deviance", "response". ask Logical: prompt plot? id.n Number extreme points label. labels Labels points (default: observation indices). ... Additional graphical parameters.

title: Diagnostic Plots for gkwreg2 Objects — plot.gkwreg2
text: Invisibly returns diagnostic data list.

title: Diagnostic Plots for gkwreg2 Objects — plot.gkwreg2
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(123) n <- 100 x <- rnorm(n) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = exp(0.5 + 0.2 * x), beta = exp(1)) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x) fit <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") plot(fit) # All 6 plots       plot(fit, which = c(2, 6)) # Q-Q and Obs vs Pred only   # }

title: Predict Method for gkwreg2 Objects — predict.gkwreg2
code: # S3 method for class 'gkwreg2' predict(   object,   newdata = NULL,   type = c("response", "parameters", "link", "quantile", "density", "variance"),   at = NULL,   se.fit = FALSE,   ... )

title: Predict Method for gkwreg2 Objects — predict.gkwreg2
text: object fitted gkwreg2 object. newdata Optional data frame prediction. omitted, uses original training data. type Type prediction: "response" Expected mean E(Y|X) (default) "parameters" distribution parameters "link" Linear predictors (η) "quantile" Quantiles specified probabilities "density" Density specified y values "variance" Conditional variance Var(Y|X) type = "quantile": probabilities. type = "density": y values. se.fit Logical: return standard errors? (yet implemented) ... Currently ignored.

title: Predict Method for gkwreg2 Objects — predict.gkwreg2
text: Depending type: "response" Numeric vector predicted means "parameters" Named list parameter vectors "link" Named list linear predictor vectors "quantile" Matrix rows per obs, cols per quantile "density" Vector density values "variance" Vector variances

title: Predict Method for gkwreg2 Objects — predict.gkwreg2
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(123) n <- 100 x <- rnorm(n) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = exp(0.5 + 0.2 * x), beta = exp(1)) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x) fit <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw")  # Predicted means pred <- predict(fit, type = "response")  # Distribution parameters params <- predict(fit, type = "parameters")  # Quantiles q <- predict(fit, type = "quantile", at = c(0.1, 0.5, 0.9)) # }

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
text: Extracts various types residuals fitted gkwreg2 model.

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
code: # S3 method for class 'gkwreg2' residuals(object, type = c("response", "pearson", "deviance", "quantile"), ...)  # S3 method for class 'gkwreg2' resid(object, type = c("response", "pearson", "deviance", "quantile"), ...)

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
text: object fitted gkwreg2 object. type Type residuals: "response" Raw residuals: y - fitted (default) "pearson" Pearson residuals: (y - mu) / sqrt(V(mu)) "deviance" Deviance residuals "quantile" Randomized quantile residuals (Dunn & Smyth) ... Currently ignored.

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
text: numeric vector residuals.

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
text: Randomized quantile residuals (type = "quantile") useful model checking follow standard normal distribution model correctly specified. computed : $$r_i = \Phi^{-1}(F(y_i; \hat\theta_i))$$ \(F\) CDF fitted distribution.

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
text: Dunn, P.K. Smyth, G.K. (1996). Randomized quantile residuals. Journal Computational Graphical Statistics, 5(3), 236-244.

title: Residuals for gkwreg2 Objects — residuals.gkwreg2
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(123) n <- 100 x <- rnorm(n) y <- gkwdist::rkw(n, alpha = exp(0.5 + 0.2 * x), beta = exp(1)) df <- data.frame(y = y, x = x) fit <- gkwreg2(y ~ x, data = df, family = "kw") res <- residuals(fit, type = "quantile") qqnorm(res) qqline(res)  # }

title: gkwreg2 0.1.1
text: Added GitHub Actions R-CMD-check workflow Comprehensive README badges examples Full API compatibility gkwreg package

title: gkwreg2 0.1.1
text: Fixed predict.gkwreg2() correctly access coef_list instead flat coefficients Fixed NA handling variance-covariance matrix diagonal check Added required stats imports (AIC, BIC, resid, etc.) Corrected gkw_control() use factr/pgtol L-BFGS-B optimizer

title: gkwreg2 0.1.1
text: examples now include complete data generation code Removed VignetteBuilder without vignettes Cleaned DESCRIPTION metadata

title: gkwreg2 0.1.0
text: Pure RcppArmadillo implementation (TMB dependency) Support 7 distribution families: gkw, bkw, kkw, ekw, mc, kw, beta Extended formula syntax: y ~ alpha_formula | beta_formula | ... Analytical gradients via gkwdist package Multiple optimizers: nlminb, BFGS, L-BFGS-B, Nelder-Mead, CG Parameter clamping numerical stability Moment-based starting values robust convergence

title: gkwreg2 0.1.0
text: coef(), vcov(), confint() - coefficient extraction inference logLik(), AIC(), BIC(), nobs() - model fit statistics fitted(), residuals() - fitted values residuals (response, pearson, quantile) predict() - predictions (response, parameters, link, quantile, density, variance) summary(), print() - model summaries anova() - likelihood ratio tests nested models plot() - 6 diagnostic plot types formula(), model.frame(), model.matrix(), update() - model utilities

title: gkwreg2 0.1.0
text: Full output structure compatibility gkwreg coefficient naming convention (colon-separated) class inheritance: c("gkwreg2", "gkwreg")

title: gkwreg2 0.1.0
text: 370+ unit tests covering families methods R CMD check –-cran: 0 errors, 0 warnings
